abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability likely, yet, institutional
            development impacts were only modest. It is highlighted that
            while in principle, the project design, neglected short-term
            upgrade of urban areas in favor of the preparation of a
            long-term infrastructure investment plan, it proved a sound
            and valid approach. However, the project revealed the limits
            of the community-based approach to addressing broader urban
            development, and management issues. Future operations should
            consider the following lessons to make project impacts more
            sustainable and replicable. For the project to scale up its
            impact, a participatory investment program should have been
            combined with a comprehensive support, and capacity building
            program for municipalities. In the future, operations should
            rather expand from narrowly defined community-based
            infrastructure development, to broader municipal operations.
            Particular attention should be given to strengthening urban
            regulatory functions, e.g., preparation of urban plans and
            definition of building permit procedures, all of which aim
            to promote, guide, regulate, and support private sector
            development. Noticeably, any follow-up project should have a
            substantially larger component for upgrading primary
            infrastructure. Project experience made it clear that land
            tenure issues in peri-urban areas are complex, and involve
            serious social and political implications, and, it is not
            within the jurisdiction of the municipalities. Therefore,
            there may be a need for a separate project, specifically
            focusing on land tenure, and land registration aspects.
